document_metadata.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer’s disease

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: By contrast, the parenchyma of the CNS is devoid of lymphatic vasculature2; in the brain, removal of cellular debris and toxic molecules, such as amyloid-β peptides, is mediated by a combination of transcellular transport mechanisms across the blood−brain and blood−cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) barriers7–9, phagocytosis and digestion by resident microglia and recruited monocytes and/or macrophages10,11, as well as CSF influx and ISF efflux through a paravascular (glymphatic) route12–14

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Analysis of lymphoid and myeloid cell populations in the meninges (Extended Data Fig. 9d) demonstrated a significant increase in the number of macrophages upon lymphatic ablation compared to both control groups (Extended Data Fig. 9e), which might be correlated with increased amyloid-β deposition and inflammation in the meninges

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Staining for amyloid-β in the brains of nine patients with Alzheimer’s disease and eight controls without Alzheimer’s disease (Extended Data Table 1) revealed, as expected, marked parenchymal deposition of amyloid-β in the brains of patients with Alzheimer’s disease, but not in the brains of the controls without Alzheimer’s disease (Extended Data Fig. 9l, m)

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Notably, when compared to tissue from controls, all samples from patients with Alzheimer’s disease demonstrated striking vascular amyloid-β pathology in the cortical leptomeninges (Extended Data Fig. 9l, m) and amyloid-β deposition in the dura mater adjacent to the superior sagittal sinus (Fig. 3i, j) or further away from the sinus (Fig. 3k, l)

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: These findings showed that prominent meningeal amyloid-β deposition observed in patients with Alzheimer’s disease is also observed in mouse models of Alzheimer’s disease after meningeal lymphatic vessel ablation

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Macrophages in the dura of cases with Alzheimer’s disease were also found in close proximity to amyloid-β deposits (Fig. 3l)

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Extracellular deposition of amyloid-β aggregates, the main constituent of senile plaques, is considered to be a pathological hallmark of Alzheimer’s disease that contributes to neuronal dysfunction and behavioural changes

links.evidence: Notably, although the fold change in significantly altered genes after lymphatic ablation and MWM was moderate (−1.79 < log2(fold change) < 1.69), functional enrichment analysis (Extended Data Fig. 5o, p) revealed changes in gene sets associated with neurodegenerative diseases, such as Huntington’s, Parkinson’s and Alzheimer’s disease (Extended Data Fig. 5o)

links.evidence: Ageing also leads to progressive lymphatic vessel dysfunction in peripheral tissues

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: The reported findings that ageing is also associated with peripheral lymphatic dysfunction led us to hypothesize that the deterioration of meningeal lymphatic vessels underlies some aspects of age-associated cognitive decline

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Indeed, and in agreement with a previous study, old mice demonstrate reduced brain perfusion by CSF macromolecules compared to young counterparts (Extended Data Fig. 6a, b)

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Enrichment analysis revealed, however, changes in gene sets involved in immune and inflammatory responses, phospholipid metabolism, extracellular matrix organization, cellular adhesion and endothelial tube morphogenesis, all of which suggest that there are functional alterations in meningeal LECs with age (Fig. 2c).

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Here we show that meningeal lymphatic vessels have an essential role in maintaining brain homeostasis by draining macromolecules from the CNS (both CSF and ISF) into the cervical lymph nodes

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Here we show that meningeal lymphatic vessels have an essential role in maintaining brain homeostasis by draining macromolecules from the CNS (both CSF and ISF) into the cervical lymph nodes

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Together, three different models of impaired meningeal lymphatic function (pharmacological, surgical and genetic) showed a significant impact on brain perfusion by CSF macromolecules

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: These findings, as has been suggested previously, demonstrate that the efflux of parenchymal and/or ISF macromolecules and the drainage of these macromolecules into dCLNs are impaired as a consequence of meningeal lymphatic ablation, thus functionally connecting meningeal lymphatics with CSF influx and ISF efflux mechanisms

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Treatment of young mice with AAV1-CM-mVEGF-C resulted in a significant increase in meningeal lymphatic vessel diameter, without affecting blood vessel coverage (Extended Data Fig. 6k–m)

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Treatment of old mice (at 20–24 months) with AAV1-CMV-mVEGF-C also resulted in increased lymphatic vessel diameter (compared to AAV1-CMV-eGFP) without detectable off-target effects on the meningeal blood vasculature coverage and on meningeal and/or brain vascular haemodynamics (Fig. 2e–h and Extended Data Fig. 6n–p)

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: This VEGF-C treatment led to a significant increase in the function of meningeal lymphatic vessels in old mice, whereas young–adult mice did not respond to the treatment (Extended Data Fig. 7d, e), probably due to the ceiling effect of their existing capacity to drain OVA-A647

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Moreover, viral expression of mVEGF-C did not significantly affect the diameter of meningeal lymphatic vessels, the level of amyloid-β in the CSF, or amyloid-β deposition in the hippocampus (Extended Data Fig. 8g–n)

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: However, AAV1-CMV-mVEGF-C treatment resulted in significant improvement in the latency to platform and in the percentage of allocentric navigation strategies, in the MWM reversal at 12–14 months (Extended Data Fig. 7q, t) and in the MWM acquisition and reversal at 20–22 months (Extended Data Fig. 7r, u), compared to AAV1-CMV-eGFP-treated age-matched mice

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Increased expression of VEGF-C in the adult brain has previously been shown to boost proliferation of neural stem cells in the hippocampus

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: The beneficial effect of mVEGF-C treatment in mice from the sham group, which performed significantly better in the NLR (Fig. 2n, o) and MWM (Fig. 2p–r) tests, was abrogated in mice in which the CSF-draining lymphatic vessels had been ligated

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Accordingly, the drainage of CSF macromolecules into dCLNs was significantly higher in sham-operated mice treated with mVEGF-C compared to all other groups (Fig. 2s, t)

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Independently of the model, the level of CSF tracer drained into the dCLNs was comparable between transgenic mice with Alzheimer’s disease and age-matched wild-type littermates (Extended Data Fig. 8p–s)

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Moreover, viral expression of mVEGF-C did not significantly affect the diameter of meningeal lymphatic vessels, the level of amyloid-β in the CSF, or amyloid-β deposition in the hippocampus (Extended Data Fig. 8g–n)

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Similarly, the morphology and coverage of meningeal lymphatic vessels did not differ between wild-type and 5xFAD mice at 3–4 months of age (Extended Data Fig. 8t, u)

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Transcranial delivery (through a thinned skull surface) of hydrogel-encapsulated VEGF-C peptide also resulted in increased diameter of meningeal lymphatics in young and old mice (Extended Data Fig. 7a–c)

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Treatment with VEGF-C156S resulted in a significant increase in meningeal lymphatic diameter (Extended Data Fig. 7i, j), drainage of tracer from the CSF (Extended Data Fig. 7k, l), and paravascular influx of tracer into the brains of old mice (Extended Data Fig. 7m, n)

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Treatment with VEGF-C156S resulted in a significant increase in meningeal lymphatic diameter (Extended Data Fig. 7i, j), drainage of tracer from the CSF (Extended Data Fig. 7k, l), and paravascular influx of tracer into the brains of old mice (Extended Data Fig. 7m, n)

citation.name: Functional aspects of meningeal lymphatics in ageing and Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Analysis of lymphoid and myeloid cell populations in the meninges (Extended Data Fig. 9d) demonstrated a significant increase in the number of macrophages upon lymphatic ablation compared to both control groups (Extended Data Fig. 9e), which might be correlated with increased amyloid-β deposition and inflammation in the meninges
